page.title: 04Soils and Hedges
page.content: The Jurassic clays produce a heavy, sticky type of soil, almost impervious to water, difficult to work when wet and often rock hard in dry weather; but it is fertile and fairly alkaline. Land drains have been installed over much of the farmland, which makes it more suitable for ploughing and re-seeding with grass, or other arable crops. The cornbrash in the north and east of the block is better drained and more workable. As most of the land is used at times for grazing animals, the fields are mostly of medium size with secure boundaries, usually hedges. These often grow on a bank of earth or stone, perhaps originally a dry stone wall. The hedges, formerly laid, are now mechanically trimmed to about six feet, which keeps them dense and stock proof.
